Project Description: Mapping the therapy to better target innovation opportunities

Text:
There are multiple tests used to diagnose kidney disease. 
The first is the urine 'dip stick' test. In this test, strips of paper covered with small squares of chemical reagent are dipped in a urine specimen and the resulting color of each small square of chemical reagent is read against a chart on the bottle. These tests identify the presence of blood cells and protein in the urine. The presence of blood cells and protein in the urine indicate that there is damage to the nephrons.
The second type of test is a blood test. This measures the blood levels of urea, which is a waste by-product from the breakdown of dietary protein, and creatinine a waste product produced by the muscles. Urea and creatinine levels in the blood are good indicators of kidney function.
Creatinine levels are thought to be more reliable than blood urea levels, or BUN, as blood urea levels can vary depending upon diet, some medications, the presence of bleeding and so forth. Creatinine, on the other hand, is a product of muscle metabolism. An individual's muscle mass typically remains fairly stable from day to day, so the creatinine level in the blood is more or less constant.

If patient presented acutely, they were often started on hemo even if their modality of choice in pre-dialysis clinic had been PD (Polson and Iverson, 2006).  A number of reasons for this were identified, including ease of insertion of hemo access and nephrologists feeling in control as their training allowed them to insert a hemo catheter, dialyze and discharge a patient on their first renal replacement therpay visit without relying on other members of the multidisclinary team or requiring intervention by a renal surgeon.

Percutaneous versus open placement of peritoneal dialysis catheters

Despite its several advantages, peritoneal dialysis (PD) is currently an underutilized form of renal placement therapy (1). The problem of PD catheter insertion is one of the main reasons for this underutilization, and emphasis has been placed on catheter placement by a nephrologist to increase PD utilization and to improve patient survival (2). In Korea, 30% of PD catheter placements were performed by a nephrologist, and from among several techniques, the classical trocar technique is still widely used by those nephrologists (3). However, serious complications such as bowel perforation or hemoperitoneum occasionally occur with the use of this method (4), and sometimes the PD catheter is inserted into the preperitoneal space. These problems make nephrologists reluctant to personally perform PD catheter insertions. Furthermore, few surgeons are committed to PD catheter insertion, which means that patients must wait for PD (2). 

Other PD catheter insertion methods include the surgical, the peritoneoscopic, and the modified Seldinger techniques (4). Of those techniques, the modified Seldinger method, using a peel-away introducer sheath kit (“peel-away sheath method”), is the technique most easily mastered by nephrologists and has results comparable to those with the other techniques. However, peel-away kits have not been available in Korea because of low domestic needs, resulting in a lack of imports. To allow nephrologists to insert a PD catheter safely and successfully in this environment, we developed an alternative to the peel-away sheath method, using a hemodialysis (HD) catheter. The present study compares the outcomes of PD catheter insertion using our method and using the classical trocar technique
constipation, catheter migration outside the pelvis, or omental wrapping

For patients with outflow obstruction, current guidelines suggest using conservative measures first, and then, if those measures fail and the catheter has migrated, a repositioning attempt. A variety of approaches for reposition have been described: peritoneoscopy, fluoroscopy-guided techniques (2-4), laparoscopy (5), and conventional surgery. Peritoneoscopy and fluoroscopy-guided methods are feasible for nephrologists and are minimally invasive.

Before reposition is attempted, malfunctioning catheters are managed with catheter flush attempts and, for patients with clinical or radiographic evidence of constipation, with additional prescription of a bowel-cleansing product (Picolax: Ferring Laboratories, Saint-Prex, Switzerland) on top of permanent laxative treatment (senna and sodium docusate). Repositioning is performed in the PD procedure room under cardiorespiratory monitoring. Patients are not premedicated with analgesics or sedatives, with the exception of the very occasional patient requesting sedation. All manipulations are performed using strict aseptic techniques. The abdominal wall surface is prepared with chlorhexidine solution and isolated with sterile drapes. Antibacterial prophylaxis with a single dose of intravenous vancomycin (1 g) is given 1 hour before manipulation.
advantages of the fluoroscopic techniques; it is simple and minimally invasive, it can be performed on an outpatient basis, and it allows for quick catheter use
Moreover, it avoids the need for radiologic guidance. Thus, it can be a useful alternative repositioning technique for migrated Tenckhoff catheters inserted under local anesthetic.

PRE-PROCEDURE PREPARATION: A history and physical examination are performed to
uncover known conditions—such as hernias, presence of
abdominal mesh, organomegaly, prior kidney transplantation,
or past abdominal surgeries—that might complicate
placement. If the patient is on anticoagulants, they
are held 5 days before the procedure.

conscious sedation will be administered,
the patient is kept fasting for at least 6 hours before the
procedure.

Signed consent for PD catheter placement is
obtained from the patient after information has been
communicated about the procedure: its benefits, risks,
and possible alternatives; and the option to choose not
to proceed.

Signed consent for PD catheter placement is
obtained from the patient after information has been
communicated about the procedure: its benefits, risks,
and possible alternatives; and the option to choose not
to proceed.

1 Hour before treatment: Pre-procedure antibiotics are administered
intravenously:

The patient is asked to fully empty
the bladder, and if the patient has bladder dysfunction,
a Foley catheter can be used to ensure more complete
bladder drainage.

Abdominal Site Marking: Marking of the entry and exit
sites for the catheter is performed in the pre-procedure
area. Site marking can be performed using a nonsterile
double-cuff PD catheter or a commercially available stencil.
The belt line is noted in sitting and standing position
while the patient is fully dressed.

The catheter is prepared by being placed into a surgical
bowl filled with saline. The polyester fiber cuffs are
manually compressed to extrude any trapped air that
might inhibit tissue ingrowth.

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE: The
patient is placed supine on the angiographic table in
the procedure room, and preliminary ultrasonography of
the abdomen is performed to help determine the safest
puncture site (entry site) and to plan for the subcutaneous
tunnel and catheter exit site.

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE:  The safest puncture site should be determined by
grayscale ultrasonography, Doppler ultrasonography,
and fluoroscopy. To minimize the risk of inadvertent
bowel puncture, preliminary grayscale ultrasonography
is used to determine the site on the anterior abdominal
wall that has no bowel loops underneath or that has the
maximum separation between the anterior abdominal
wall and the bowel loops.

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE:   All planned sites should be marked with
a pen.
The hair on the anterior abdominal wall in the involved
area is then shaved. Shaving with a razor is considered
to create a higher risk for subsequent infection, and so
medical-grade hair clippers are used for shaving.

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE:   The abdomen is then prepped with an antiseptic scrub and
sterilely draped to provide exposure to the initial puncture
site and the expected exit site.

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE: Mild or moderate sedation is given using intravenous
midazolam hydrochloride and fentanyl citrate. Vital signs
(pulse, blood pressure, oxygen saturation) and bedside
electrocardiography are continuously monitored during
the procedure by the operating physician and a dedicated
nurse. Anesthesiology assistance is not routinely
required,

CATHETER PLACEMENT PROCEDURE: The safest initial puncture site is again confirmed by
ultrasonography. Local anesthesia using 1% lidocaine
is infiltrated within the skin and the subcutaneous and
deep tissues of the anterior abdominal wall at the anticipated
puncture site.

Ultrasound Guidance/ Fluoroscopic Guidance3/21/2018 After ultrasound-guided entry
into the peritoneal cavity, approximately 3 – 5 mL of
nonionic contrast material can be injected and visualized
under fluoroscopy

If bowel perforation occurs, the procedure is terminated
to avoid catheter infection and peritonitis. The
patient can be managed conservatively or treated with
oral ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 2 weeks, after
which the patient can return for a second attempt.

After visual confirmation of successful entry into the
peritoneal cavity, a 0.018-in. nitinol wire that accompanies
the original micro-introducer kit is threaded into
the peritoneal cavity

With the nitinol wire in
place, the 21-gauge needle is then exchanged over the
nitinol wire for the 4 or 5-French microsheath

The wire and inner stiffener of the sheath are then
removed, and contrast may again be injected through
the sheath to confirm that the sheath is in the peritoneal
cavity. A 0.035-in. guide wire is advanced through the sheath and directed toward the
pelvis under fluoroscopic guidance. The 0.035-in. wire is ideal because it allows for manipulation
around the bowel and is stiff enough to permit
catheter traction during final placement.

The 4-French microsheath is then exchanged over the
wire for a 6-French introducer sheath). Contrast can again be injected through the
sidearm of the introducer sheath to confirm the location
of the sheath in the peritoneal cavity.

A 2-cm to 4-cm incision is made at the entry site of
the introducer sheath, and blunt dissection down to the
rectus abdominis muscle is made using a finger or curved
hemostat

To separate the bowel loops and
facilitate passage of the catheter into the peritoneum,
300 – 1000 mL of normal saline can be infused through
the sidearm of the introducer sheath

The sheath is then removed, and the tract is serially
dilated over the wire with an 8-French, a 12-French, and
then a 14-French dilator . Dilatation should occur under
fluoroscopic visualization, and the dilators should be
directed caudally toward the pelvic cavity in the same
direction as the original needlestick so as to avoid the
wire and dilator being pushed into the subcutaneous
tissue superficial to the rectus abdominis muscle, rather
than through the muscle into the peritoneal cavity.

With or without serial dilation, a 16-French, 15-cm
pull-apart sheath is advanced into the peritoneal cavity over
the wire in the deep pelvic direction
